Ever wondered what successful people often have on their lips?  Itâ€™s not a hustle, itâ€™s not a strategy... itâ€™s Silence and A Smile. Sounds too easy? Maybe, but they work wonders.


Here's why:


â€“ The ultimate weapon to avoid problems.
 In a world full of noise, choosing silence gives you clarity.
 It helps you reflect, make thoughtful decisions, and prevent unnecessary conflict.


A
â€“ The magic tool to solve problems.

posts.name:
Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
posts.content:
Does less engineers = more productivity?

Salesforce stops all engineer hires in 2025 after mass layoffs for "efficiency". Is AI-first operations fixing broken math for SaaS giants? According to Benioff, it is.

Old Engineering Motion:

- Hiring targets are standard so we can grow every quarter without thinking
- Build massive teams - we'll get efficient eventually
- The VP ran Engineering at BigTech, they're perfect for our growing business
- Of course they need 7,000+ people to get things off the ground
- The growth model says we'll hit unicorn status
- Teams send over forecasts, Finance chases them, productivity drops a year later
- We have a planning meeting every month but neither Product or AI joins
- We need to pay engineers massive compensation in every region
- Our efficiency metrics are upside down, let's hire more engineers!
- "Just build a bigger team!"

New AI-First Motion (The Salesforce way, apparentlyâ€¦):

- We're building an Agentforce-led business
- Cut engineering hires by 100% in 2025
- Productivity increased by 30% with AI
- We have an "AI-first" engineering team that Benioff says "has incredible velocity"
- They don't want more engineers. Together they're proving AI can boost productivity, not just assist
- Engineering, Product, AI and Sales meet regularly to identify more automation opportunities
- The success of the business is built around AI not headcount
- Every role is measured against one metric: can AI do it better?

In a world where Salesforce's productivity jumps 30% while cutting engineering hires completely, is aligning your team around AI-first development smart, or is it just survival?

Or beyond survival, does it mean thriving?

The math is pretty clear:
â€¢ 2023: 7,000 layoffs to increase efficiency
â€¢ 2024: 700 more cuts with AI integration
â€¢ 2025: No more engineering hires, +2,000 salespeople

My feelings are mixed as it was with the Klarna news last month (interesting these press releases were made within a week of each otherâ€¦).

But I like to consider myself a realist.

How do you all feel about this? Would love to hear from engineers and founders alike...

comments.commentText:
This is SUPER interesting Alex Turnbull. As someone who sells devs for hire and team augmentation, I feel that the narrative around â€œless engineers = more productivityâ€ is nuanced and context-dependent. Salesforceâ€™s AI-first motion is impressive, but it reflects a very specific stage of maturity and scale. One where the systems, processes, and core products are already in place.
For smaller companies or startups, cutting back on engineers entirely would be counterproductive. In those environments, engineers arenâ€™t just executing, theyâ€™re wearing multiple hats, problem-solving across disciplines, and helping shape the product vision. AI can assist, but it canâ€™t fully replace that kind of adaptability and creativity.
It's why I talk a lot about a product mindset for engineering teams.

posts.name:
Poorva Shrivastava
Poorva Shrivastava
posts.content:
I Quitâ€¦. 



Six months ago, I almost quit social media before I even started. Why?

I wasnâ€™t comfortable sharing my life openly on a platform where everyone has an opinion.

But then, one day, I stopped and thought deeply about it.

Hereâ€™s what I realized:

What Do You Really Want?

Do you want money? Fame? Followers? Have you ever stopped to ask yourself what you really need?

&has become a massive industry, but hereâ€™s a question:

What happens after you reach 100K, 200K, or even 1M followers?

Here are some key points to think about:

â€¢ Followers â‰  Success: Having millions of followers doesnâ€™t guarantee brand deals or income. Many creators still struggle despite their numbers.

â€¢ Skills Matter More: Business leaders like, (Founder of Snapdeal), @Gourav Munjal have fewer than 10K followers yet earn in crores.

â€¢ Money Opens Doors: Whether you have followers or not, money creates opportunities and connections, even with influential people.

Social Media Isnâ€™t Everythingâ€¦ 

At the end of the day, itâ€™s about knowing how to create value and monetize your skills. Followers are just numbers if you donâ€™t have a plan.

What do you think? Let me know in the comments!

comments.commentText: Your insights resonate deeply, Poorva Shrivastava. It's refreshing to see a reminder that true value lies in our skills and the connections we cultivate, rather than just in follower counts. Your mission to provide education is a powerful testament to creating genuine impact. Thank you for encouraging us to reflect on what truly matters.
Priyank Ahuja Thank you for your kind words and thoughtful response. Itâ€™s true that value is created through skills, meaningful connections, and the impact we make, not just by numbers on a screen.

posts.name:
Ben Neale
Ben Neale
posts.content:
What's the most persistent myth about WordPress?

"WordPress is just a blogging tool."

Letâ€™s debunk that old chestnut with some cold, hard facts! 

Sure, WordPress started life in 2003 as a platform for bloggers. Yes, you still can see that blogging legacy in the current version of WordPress. And today, it remains the best choice for the serious blogger.

But it's 2025! WordPress is way more than "just a blogging tool." It's come a long, long way in 22 years.

Itâ€™s now the most powerful content management system (CMS) in the world, powering over 43% of the web. Itâ€™s used by everyone from small businesses to nonprofits. Household names like The New York Times, The Rolling Stones, and Amnesty International run their websites on WordPress.

Hereâ€™s just a taste of what WordPress can do:

 Build professional business websites
 Run an online shop, using the WooCommerce plugin
 Host membership sites, forums, and online courses
 Create portfolios, booking systems, and so much more...

With the WooCommerce plugin installed, WordPress is the largest e-commerce platform in the worldâ€”powering more online shops than either Shopify or Magento.

Thatâ€™s right: more businesses are running their e-commerce websites on WordPress than any other platform!

Iâ€™ve watched WordPress evolve from its humble blogging beginnings into the current powerhouse. Over the years, Iâ€™ve used it for everything from simple websites to complex projects. Its flexibility and scalability are second to none, which is why Iâ€™ll always champion it as the best tool for beginners and small businesses alike.

If youâ€™re still stuck believing that WordPress is just a blogging tool, itâ€™s time to rethink what it can do for you.

 Need help unlocking its potential? Join my FREE Facebook community for help, guidance, and support: WP WithBen -

The possibilities with WordPress are endlessâ€”limited only really by your imaginationâ€”and Iâ€™m here to help you every step of the way.

comments.commentText: I agree, even as a blogging tool 20 years ago you could build a fully functioning website but now it is so much more improved and can be used to create a top functioning website! Great post.

posts.name:
Ben Sim
Ben Sim
posts.content:
Some >$100M companies have their copywriters sticky-note these two words on their laptops. Can you guess what it is?

When I started out, I learned about this word.

But when I heard some $100M companies have their copywriters sticky-note the words â€œBe specificâ€ to their laptops - I knew I had to write a whole lesson on this.

So here goes:

Consider these two positive statements --

1) "Achieving good health"

2) "Feeling energetic enough to dance at your best friend's wedding"

The first statement, "achieving good health", is generic and broad. Everyone wants to be healthy.

But the second paints a specific, joyous picture - that feeling of having so much energy and well-being that you can not only attend but actively participate in a celebratory moment.

It ties the concept of health to a very particular, happy occasion, making it much more vivid and relatable.

This is what specificity can do. Notice that it paints a picture in your head compared to â€œachieving good healthâ€.

Now, letâ€™s look at a negative statement:

Ever felt the pang of "not having enough money"?

It stings, right?

But imagine â€œwatching your friends jet off to world adventures while you're stuck on your couch scrolling through their Instagram storiesâ€.

Hurts more, doesn't it? Again, that's the power of specificity. It paints a picture so vivid, so relatable, that readers are instantly hooked.

Hereâ€™s why specificity works:

In the vast wilderness of the internet, where anyone can claim just about anythingâ€¦

Specificity becomes your North Star. It lends you credibility. After all, only someone truly in-the-know would deal in specifics, right?

But there's more to specificity than just painting vivid images.

Specificity in numbers works too.

Consider these two pitches:

"Over 2000 moms adore this stroller!"
"Already 2781 moms trust this stroller for their little one's comfort."

Which one instantly feels more trustworthy? The latter, right?

Itâ€™s because 2000 looks very rounded off, whereas 2781 looks oddly specific.

PRO TIP: There's a weird quirk we've observed over the years. Odd numbers perform better in copy. We don't know why, but it just does. So avoid using even numbers if you can.

=====

Enjoyed this quick lesson? Get free 7-8 figure marketing tips straight to your inbox, written by me - a few times a week.

Sign up with the link in the comments.

comments.commentText: I love how specific wording can make an idea so much more memorable and engaging
Thanks for sharing this insight on the power of specificity, learned something new today!

posts.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
posts.content:
Yesterday I randomly came up with a term. 


Ideal Human Profile.

Uncertain that it was a new term
and I had not in fact previously heard it elsewhere, I posted about it.

No one seemed to have heard of it either.

Someone commented that I should Trademark it before aguru threw it into an expensive course.

I am a man of swift action, so I did.

And I am going to go the route of Volvo who were famous

for giving up their design for the 3 point seat belt to help other automakers build safer cars.

So while I will soon own the rights to "Ideal Human Profile"

my intention is to allow it's use for all.

Not because I want credit or praise, but because in my heart

I believe this is the way things are headed

And we really need to give it a solid push.

As someone who's spent 2 decades in actual sales

trust me when I tell you that people are sick of being an ICP that's

-> sold to
-> pitched to
-> put into sales funnels
-> mislead and lied to
-> overpromised and underdelivered

As a matter of fact, I am willing to bet that ICP might be the most

overused term on this platform, aside from maybe expert.

After 1000+ phone calls and building some of the most amazing relationships as a result last year

I have never been more confident about anything than I am of this.

Yours truthfully,

comments.commentText: Michael Kainatsky soon it will be in the queue at the USPTO where it will sit for 10 months before being assigned an examiner who will reject it for some random reason. When that happens, call Lara Pearson (Lara the lawyer who loves law)and sheâ€™ll sort it out for you.
Cody whatâ€™s crazy is that they take a lot of money for it and say itâ€™s none refundable for any reason.

Michael Kainatsky trust me - I know this. When i first started practicing law - getting a trademark took about a week and the examiners were pretty good about allowing trademarks as long as there was no direct competition. Last year 4/5 of my applications were denied (all filed in 2023, all assigned in late 2024.)

That's a brilliant term, and I am glad you're trademarking it Michael Kainatsky. 

After I read your post yesterday, I started thinking. I must have tried at least 2 dozen times to "nail down my ICP" and failed miserably in doing so. But the minute I try to describe who might enjoy/learn from my content (my ideal "human" profile), it becomes incredibly easier... (and for those that might be curious - no, I am NOT a coach!) LOL.

Dr. Identifying the ICP is among the most difficult things to do because people have to eliminate so many people, and focus on a niche subset. Itâ€™s a lot of pressure and everyone is out there doing it. Thatâ€™s why posts are so bland.
